item.title: Report E-2023050488
item.description:
Report E-2023050488

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-09T18:11:31+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-05-18
  • City: PORT ALLEN
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: During the quality control inspection process for arriving drums to Veolia's 10-day intransit facility in Port Allen, LA, a small puddle of unknown liquid (approximately ½ cup) was observed at the edge of a pallet. After informing the supervisor on duty, the pallet was pulled aside and inspected. One drum of waste was found with a pinhole leak ~3 inches from the edge of the bottom of the drum. The leak appeared to not be from stress or gradual wear, and it's believed that the drum may have been compromised during the generator's loading process or a manufacturing fault in the packaging exists since this is the second time an incident like this has occurred with this generator. The drum was overpacked into a salvage drum, and the spill was cleaned using oil dry.

item.title: Report E-2023050485
item.description:
Report E-2023050485

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-09T18:11:31+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-05-18
  • City: SHREVEPORT
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LSL experienced a UN2831 Methyl Chloroform release from a 55-gallon metal drum due to a forklift puncture impacting their dock floor. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed terminal personnel applied Oil Dri to the impacted area. Approximately 20-gallons of product released to a 20' x 30' area of the dock floor due to a forklift puncture. Additional absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted area. The damaged drum containing approximately 35-gallons of product was placed into a 95-gallon poly over pack. The impacted absorbents and cleanup debris were placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: The tote was inspected by Veolia upon receipt from the customer and showed no signs of leaks or damage to the tote of any kind. However, it was noticed that the the closure on the tote was loose. The closure was tightened and secured before loading onto the truck. Upon arrival at Veolia's 10-Day facility in Port Allen, LA, saturation was noticed on the trailer floor. Upon further inspection, the tote was identified as having a significant size crack in the top corner of the container that was not present at the time of pickup. It is believed that the container failed during transit. Approximately 5 gallons of material was spilled.

item.title: Report E-2023040235
item.description:
Report E-2023040235

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-09T18:11:31+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-13
  • City: HORNBECK
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR INWAY, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On April 13, 2023, at 1533 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar Inway personnel in Hornbeck, Louisiana regarding the release of approximately 1 gallon of Sodium Permanganate 10% (Permanganates, inorganic, aqueous solution, n.o.s., (Sodium Permanganate), UN3214, 5.1, II) from (1) 330-gallon poly tote. The release was contained to a 2’ x 2’ area of the trailer floor and was reportedly due to improper loading prior to transport. No drains or waterways were affected by the release. Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release using absorbents and the proper PPE. The remaining product in the damaged tote was transferred to a new poly tote and forwarded on to the consignee. The released product and all other waste generated were containerized in (1) 55-gallon poly drum; the damaged tote was staged for disposal as well. The waste drum and damaged tote were then transported offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

item.title: Report X-2023040209
item.description:
Report X-2023040209

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-09T18:11:31+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-04
  • City: Harahan
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On April 4, 2023 at 0005 hrs., TILX 110117 (Residue Last Contained, Hydrochloric Acid / UN 1780 / Class 8) was observed venting from the top during switching operations at CN Mays Yard. The railcar was isolated and all departments notified. The CN DGO responded. Upon arrival and approaching the railcar, vapors were observed coming from the top. Upon closer inspection, vapors were observed coming from a 3 bolt flange below the vapor line valve. The bolts were checked and 2 of the 3 bolts were found to be less than tool tight. 1 of the 2 bolts was able to be tightened, the other bolt has to be changed due to deterioration from the acid. Once the replacement bolts was installed and tightened, the leak was stopped. The exterior of the railcar was decontaminated. The railcar will be held at CN Mays yard for requalification.

item.title: Report E-2023040130
item.description:
Report E-2023040130

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-09T18:11:31+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-03
  • City: MONROE
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: SOUTHEASTERN FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Around 5pm central time I received a call from Toby Owens who works for Bozeman. Toby told me he was fueling up at the Loves at 335 LA-594, Monroe, LA, 71203 and was doing a walk around of set and noticed a pool of paint (UN1263, Paint, 3, PGIII) on ground and that it was still leaking from his rear pup (287281F). Toby notified central dispatch and they told him to contact Billy or myself. I contacted Hazmat One at 524pm and told them to make all the necessary phone calls and to take all waste with them. Toby mentioned it started to rain and Loves Truck Stop helped contain the spill from spreading more. Hazmat One arrived at Loves at 835pm to start cleaning spill. Hazmat One is renting a boom to unload trailer to clean up. They believe the leak is coming from a drum in nose of trailer. They projected a time of 600am to have spill cleaned up. Release was caused by a nail in the pallet the drums were loaded on. The nail during transit had punctured a hole in the bottom on one drum. Majority of material had leaked into the trailer

  • Carrier/Reporter: UNION PACIFIC RAILROAD COMPANY INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Union Pacific Railroad yard personnel reported a tank car possibly leaking in the Anchorage Yard in Port Allen LA. Haz Mat Manager Tom Robinson was called for response. Mgr. Robinson discovered that the tank car was leaking the from the pressure relief device. The PRD had misaligned O-ring. The O-ring was properly putting back in place and the car stopped releasing vapors. The car was resealed and will be transferred at a later date because it was involved in a roll-over derailment on 3-29-2023.

item.title: Report X-2023040082
item.description:
Report X-2023040082

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-08T21:10:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-03-23
  • City: Harahan
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Illinois Central Railroad Company
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 2
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On March 23, 2023 at 1744 hrs., 2 CN Mechanical employees were walking next to CN Mays yard track NM05 and smelled an odor. They immediately experienced, difficulty breathing, tightening of chest and irritation of the eyes. The CN DGO was notified and responded. When the DGO arrived and approached the area, he observed vapors coming from the top of railcar DBCX 201581. The DGO also observed liquid streaming down the sides and onto the ground. Upon closer investigation, liquid was observed coming from the combination housing. The combination housing was secured by seal # A3784563. The seal was removed and the combination housing opened. Liquid was observed coming from the base of the liquid line valve were it connects to the pressure plate. The valve was able to be shifted by hand. Heavy corrosion was observed on the liquid line valve fastener bolts. The internal pressure was relieved which stopped the release of product. The liquid line valve bolts were able to be tightened, which secured the liquid line valve to the pressure plate.

item.title: Report X-2023031376

Report X-2023031376

  • City: NEW ORLEANS

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: NORFOLK SOUTHERN
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 1
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: UTLX 679959 was observed by Mechanical Department personnel with a small steady stream of liquid coming from the threads of the BOV cap. Car moved to isolation track and response contractor called to investigate. Tightened BOV cap and release slowed to a fast drip. Cycled BOV multiple times and leak did not stop or slow further. BOV was very hard to operate. Contents of UTLX 679958 was transferred to another tank car. BOV cap/auxiliary valve assembly was removed and found the primary BOV would not close completely. Gasket in BOV cap was deteriorated and packed with sludge. Score marks observed in metal of ball valve of primary BOV.

  • Description: On March 07, 2023, one (1) 270-gallon tote containing UN3082 was damaged and released approximately 150 gallons of product to the trailer interior, dock floor, and pavement beneath the trailer. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hazmat Special Services (HMSS) to remediate the impacted surfaces. HMSS personnel transferred the remaining virgin product to a new 330-gallon tote for continued shipping. The crew used absorbents to clean off the impacted tote and contained all waste in fifteen (15) 55-gallon drums for disposal. On March 08, 2023, HMSS returned to the site and utilized a power washer to finish remediating the site and contained all UN3082-impacted water in the previously mentioned drums.

  • Description: Approximately@ 1730 on 2/6/2023, A leaking tote on trailer 535697 was reported to the SEFL BTR facility Quality Assurance Leader. Immediately, documents to determine the type of chemical were referenced& measures to contain the spill were performed. Quick dry absorbent, absorbent boom, absorbent pad,& cardboard were all used to prevent further spread & leakage of the chemical. Please note that none of this chemical entered any type of waterway or stream. It was contained to trailer 535697. The non-damaged freight was off-loaded from the trailer onto cardboard for containment as well. The damaged tote was located and manuvered to stop leak, it was determined that the tote had been punctured in the front by a smaller pallet causing a significant cut in the plastic body. The remaining product in the damaged tote was transferred into a non-damaged contingency tote located on site. SEFL safety had already been contacted as well as HAZMAT 1. OMI Environmental Services arrived@ SEFL BTR approximately around 1845& LA State Police DOT arrived shortly after to commence clean-upofthe spill. ,

  • City: WESTLAKE

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: THE KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN RAILWAY COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 00:42 on 2/6/2023, a Kansas City Southern Railway (KCS) Trainmaster reported smelling LPG gas in the KCS Mossville rail yard located in Westlake, LA. The KCS Environmental & Hazmat Department mobilized a railroad qualified response contractor to investigate and mitigate the leak. Responders found GATX 109869 to be leaking at the B-End liquid line valve secondary closure plug, which was installed, but was found to be less than tool tight. Responders attempted to tighten the B-End liquid valve, which appeared to be in the closed position, using more force; however, the leak persisted after the valve was tightened as much as possible. Responders secured the secondary closure plug tool-tight to stop the leak. The shipper was notified of the NAR and advised of defective valve so they could make arrangements for a movement approval to move car back to origin for unloading and then to home shop for repairs. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a 'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier does not have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.

  • Incident Date: 2023-02-27
  • City: BATON ROUGE

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On February 27, 2023 at 1110 hrs. , CN Transportation conductor advised while switching railcars he felt a liquid splash on his left arm. He looked at the railcar next to him and observed the sides were wet. The DGO was contacted and responded to the scene. Upon arrival and speaking with the conductor, a detailed inspection was performed on the railcar. Upon approaching the railcar, there were visible indications of where a liquid had sprayed on the railcar and dried. Upon closer inspection of the railcar, the manway was secured with an intact security seal. The manway bolts were checked for proper securement, 2 of the bolts were found to be less than tool tight. An air monitor was used near the manway, which alerted to elevated LEL and VOC readings. The manway seal was removed, and manway gasket inspected. No exceptions being observed with the gasket, the manway was properly secured, and new security seal attached. The railcar was released back into transportation.

item.title: Report I-2023020061
item.description:
Report I-2023020061

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-08T21:10:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-01-17
  • City: Shreveport
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: THE KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN RAILWAY COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 1/17/2023 at around 10:49 AM, Kansas City Southern Railway's(KCS) Environmental& Hazmat Department was made aware by KCS Mechanical that a loaded Argon car, BOCX 3038, was Ieaklng from the fittings cabinet while in the KCS Shreveport, LA railyard. A railroad qualified response contractor was mobilized to mitlgate the leak. Upon arrival, responders observed a small drlp from BOCX 3038's left side cabinet. The cabinet security seal was removed and cabinet door opened. Ice build up was observed on V-29 Pressure Build Vapor return valve assembly, V-9 Manual Vent Valve assembly, and the Road Relief Isolation Valve. the Road Relief valve was observed in the open position with a small vapor leak emanating from the valve stem/packing nut assembly. The Road Relief isolation valve packing nut was secured tool tight via wrench application and the valve handle was actuated to the closed position. Water was applied to defrost all valves and fittings. After defrostlng and approximately 10 minute observation, no further leaks were observed. Responders applied zip ties to the valve handles to secure them In the closed position. To ensure the car had been properly secured, BOCX 3038 was evaluated the following morning. The car was determined to be ventlng normally without defect. Once securement was verified, the car was released back into transportation. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best Information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier does not have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.

  • Description: On 1/26/2023 at 2:30pm Environmental and Hazmat became aware of a Ieaking tank car in the Shreveport Yard. Mechanical personnel reported the TILX 284448, Crude Oil/Load, to be Ieaklng from the top manway area. KCS mobillzed a railroad qualified response contractor to investigate and mitigate the leak. Upon inspection, the contractor identified the liquid line valve to be in the open position with secondary closure plug less than tool tight. Resulting release was approx. 1 gallon. Corrective action taken was to move liquid line valve to the closed position and secure the secondary closure plug to a tool tight state. Once car was secured it was released back into transportation. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier does not have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.

  • Description: On 1-5-2023 at 1230 personnel in the CSXT Gentilly Yard discovered CTCX733533, a loaded tank car of Styrene Monomer, Stabilized leaking from vacuum relief valve. The car was isolated and Americas Styrenics were notified (CHEMTREC Report #2023010500192). SPSI, a CSXT response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found that vapors were being released from the vacuum relief valve. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper Kevin Wheat; 832-381-4624. Contractor personnel released pressure and removed the Vacuum Relief Valve and replaced it with a thread plug. SPSI applied 5lbs of nitrogen to the car and checked for leaks. No leaks detected. An approved OTMA will be required prior to movement to destination. This incident did not require a special switching move.

The spill consisted of a 55-gallon metal drum of UN2922 "Dabco BL 17", which was punctured at the bottom. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup and containment. At 0947 ET, contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 25-gallons of product released due to a forklift puncture. The material impacted a 10' x 20' area of the trailer and 10' x 10' area of the concrete lot below. The damaged drum was collected into a 95-gallon poly overpack. Absorbents were then worked into the impacted areas and collected into two 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

DescribePack: The paint cans were bent and cracked on the top of the lid, which caused internal leakage. There was also no inner packing for the paint cans to prevent damage to them. DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: The package was already in a red tote in the hazmat area to be processed properly.

item.title: Report E-2022120395
item.description:
Report E-2022120395

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-08T21:10:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-12-08
  • City: PORT ALLEN
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 1048 ET, XPO Terminal LBL contacted ERTS to report a spill that occurred inside of a trailer and spilled out onto the ground beneath it in Port Allen, LA. The spill consisted of an unknown product which released from a 55 gallon poly drum, due to an adjacent pallet that punctured the drum while offloading the drums from the trailer. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately all 55-gallons of UN3098 Hyperflex (AFCO 4365) released from a 55-gallon poly drum to the trailer floor and asphalt parking lot in a 10' x 10' area due to a puncture. The damaged drum was containerized into an 85-gallon poly overpack. Impacted pallets were cut up and placed into two 55-gallon poly drums. Water and sodium bicarb were then utilized to neutralize the impacted areas. All spent absorbents were containerized into four 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • City: Livonia

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Hazardous Materials Manager Tom Robinson found this car doing inspections in the Livonia Yard with the air valve plug less than tool tight and the valve handle in the open position. Mgr. Robinson detected vapors coming from the open valve and closed it. The plug was properly tightened, and no further remediation was necessary. The handle needed to be removed from the valve to close the valve completely. Mgr. Robinson told the shipper to get a movement approval because the handle was removed from the valve stem and the car needed to be sent to certified shop for a proper repair. The shipper got an OTMA-3 and the car was released.

  • Description: On November 8, 2022, at 0236 EST, XPO Logistics Terminal LSL experienced an approximate 2-gallon release of UN1760 “Sikafloor-293 Part B” from a 5-gallon metal pail. The release impacted the trailer floor due to a pallet nail puncture. No soils, drains, or waterways were reported to have been impacted. ERTS dispatched E3 Environmental to conduct all on site cleanup operations. On November 8, 2022, at 0635 EST, E3 personnel arrived on site and confirmed approximately 2-gallons of product released to a 15' x 15' area of the trailer floor due to a pallet nail puncture. Absorbents were worked into the impacted area and then collected along with the damaged pail into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: On November 8, 2022, one (1) 55-gallon drum containing Heptane (UN1206) was damaged during transit and released approximately fifteen (15) gallons of product to the trailer interior and asphalt ground. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC, who dispatched a crew from OMI Environmental Solutions (OMI) to complete the necessary corrective actions. OMI personnel utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the impacted surfaces, then containerized all Heptane-impacted material into one (1) 55-gallon drum and one (1) 40-gallon contractor bag for disposal.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Description: SequenceEvent: The package was brought to QA at unload by a package handler. The package was wet on its side and the QA from called on the authorized QA for HazMat. QA got the proper equipment to move package away from unload and away from people to be exposed by the strong smell. Then asked if everyone who was around the package and who carried the package. They said they were okay. DescribePack: The canisters for the denatured alcohol was found with one out six damaged. The top of the lid where the cap was, it was shown to be bent which caused the cap to be loose and caused the leakage. There was no inner packing for the canisters inside the package, they all fitted in the box, but the box could've used some inner packing to keep the canisters from getting damaged. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The hazmat was immediately put in a red tote and transported to the hazmat cage to be process properly.

item.title: Report X-2022110554
item.description:
Report X-2022110554

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-08T21:10:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-10-27
  • City: BATON ROUGE
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: 1. X-2022110554 SequenceEvent: A QA member found the package at the chute area and notified me that it was some paint. I dropped what I was doing and headed to the chute. On closer inspection the box did not have the d.o.t label on the box. I transported the package with the proper tools to the hazmat so it can be processed properly. DescribePack: The Paint cans was found with one paint can lid bent and spilled all over the other cans. The package itself was possibly not stacked correctly in the trailer causing the damage. The small hole on the lid was enough to spill out a lot of it. There was no D.O.T label on the side of the box, the symbol where the D.O.T was suppose to be wasn't there. DurationRel: 5 and MitigateEffect: I removed the package from the chute and thankfully there was no paint on the chute. 2. X-2022110555 SequenceEvent: Management notified QA that there was three boxes had yellow paint on them. QA rushed to unload to check for the packages. The damaged paint box was found in the trailer, damaged. QA immediately got to repacking on the packages that was wet from the paint and then process the actual paint package. DescribePack: The paint cans was possibly damaged due to incorrect stacking on the trailer which caused the paint can lids to be bent and then the paint spilled inside. The paint got on multiple boxes outside of its own. The paint cans was packed with just some inner corrugated liners inside, the corrugated liners are connected to the box when you open it up. That was the only inner packing inside. DurationRel: 0 and MitigateEffect: The wet packages from the paint was removed from trailer and placed on pallet so QA can process and repacked immediately.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver stated he has a small slow leak coming from trailer, 1 drop every 4-5 seconds, leak is on main flange between tank and external valve. The driver noticed the leak while inspecting the trailer at the Love’s Truck Stop in Rayne, LA. Less than a cup is believed to have leaked and was contained. Groendyke dispatched a contractor to the site with hopes of correcting the problem but they were unable to stop the leak thereby requiring the trailer to be transloaded. At the State Trooper's request, the trailer was moved to parking lot of an adjacent terminal. State Trooper Wiltz requested a call back from an Eastman subject matter expert with detail knowledge of the material. Two plant employees were able to provide the required information. The transloading was completed at 6:15 pm. The trailer has been taken to the carrier terminal and will be returned to the plant as soon as an appointment is provided. There were no injuries related to this incident.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-08T21:10:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-09-06
  • City: SCOTT
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 6, 2022, XPO Logistics Terminal LFY reported an approximate 1 gallon release of UN2924 EMBR11678A” from a 330 gallon poly tote. The top body of the poly tote was discovered punctured in the trailer upon arrival. One gallon released onto the trailer floor only. ERTS dispatched OMI for cleanup and containment operations. On September 6, 2022 at 1030 EST, OMI personnel arrived onsite for cleanup operations. OMI confirmed approximately 1 gallon of product impacted a 5ft x 5ft area of trailer floor. The cause of release was a puncture to the top of the tote. LA State police officer Thomas Chance was onsite and arranged for the shipper to deliver a new tote for the remaining product. OMI transferred the remaining product into the new tote and cut up the old poly tote. The spilled product was cleaned with granular absorbents and pads, which were containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum with the damaged tote body. All waste remained onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • City: NEW ORLEANS

  • Carrier/Reporter: HAZMAT ENVIRONMENTAL GROUP, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: HazMat driver was pulling a rental tanker and heard "popping" noise and pulled off highway onto the shoulder to investigate. He did not find anything. He drove approx. 5 more miles and then heard another noise and pulled into an abandon weigh station. He got out of his tractor and saw material down both sides of trailer and went atop discovering material was coming from washout cap. He attempted to tighten the cap but it was already tight. He cleaned the crashbox area and verified that no material hit the ground and that leaking had stopped. Emergency Response Services, Haz-Mat One, was called and their contractor, ES & H came out the following morning to replace the gasket and cap. It was found that the threads on the cap were cross threaded.

item.title: Report I-2022100032
item.description:
Report I-2022100032

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-08T21:10:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-07-23
  • City: Shreveport
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: THE KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN RAILWAY COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 7/23/2022 at 11:48 AM, Kansas City Southern Railway's(KCS) Environmental& Hazmat Department became aware that loaded Ethyl Mercaptan tank car UTLX 900604 was emanatlng an odor at the Car Shop located in the KCS Shreveport rail yard. The Car Shop was instructed to remove the car for them shop and to spot the car so responders could investigate the odor. A railroad qualified response contractor was mobilized to investigate and mitigate the release. Upon arrival, responders found no visible signs of release after opening the protective housing. With the use of a Multi-Rae 4.Gas PID air monitor, the leak was detected at the sample valve end plug. Responders found the sample valve and the sample valve end plug were both less than tool tight. With the use of a wrench, the the sample valve and the sample valve end plug were rendered tool tight. After approximately a 20-minute wait time, the closures were checked again with the Multi-Rae meter to assure that the leak was secured. The Multi-Rae meter reading was non-detect. In addition, olfactory senses could not detect an odor. Estimated release was one quart. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier does not have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.

Product did leave the containment due to the rupture being on the low side of the containment pit. Pre delivery line was signed by the customer, and there is no site gauge for the driver to verify tank level. Customer states it looks like there may have been too much product ordered. The site supervisor stated Customer is taking care of cleanup of the spill. and she verified that the bottom of the tank blew out.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was identified as damaged by the driver (Route #428) at the recipient's location. The driver stated that her truck was poorly loaded, with multiple packages marked "fragile" in poor positions and upside down. Once she arrived to Exxon Chemical, she was able to identify the package's damage by its outer appearance and distinct odor. The package did not leak on any other packages or onto the bed of her truck. The package was returned to the station and qualified QA relocated the package to the hazmat cage. DescribePack: The 4L bottle had a loose cap which resulted in the leakage. DurationRel: 5 and MitigateEffect: Package was relocated to the hazmat cage once it was brought back to the station.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Driver, BC and package handler from pre-load said package was leaking and omitting a smell at pre-load. Package was pulled from truck. At some point someone put the package back on the truck. The driver smelled something and pulled over. At that time he noticed the package was on his truck again and placed it in 2 trash bags. When he returned to the terminal at end of day, QA was notified there was a damage on the truck and the driver put the package in a plastic bucket on its side. When I arrived to the truck I noticed a strong smell. I immediately checked DSW to see if it was a HAZMAT. It was a hazmat so I pulled the plastic container to a safe area, got all the appropriate PPE, and got the Hazmat safely contained. DescribePack: The lid was loose on the glass container, no cracks or other flaws were observed. DurationRel: 8 and MitigateEffect: Once the package was identified as a hazmat proper procedures were followed to get the spill contained

  • Description: At 0718 EST, ERTS was contacted by XPO Logistics (LSL) about a cargo release. It was reported that due to a forklift puncture approximately .5 pounds of Securiganth Etch Cleaner C (Hazardous - UN3260) was released. The caller stated that the released product was contained to the dock floor. ERTS dispatched E3 to conduct cleanup. At 0945 ET, E3 personnel arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5 pounds of product released to a 1’ x 1’ area of the dock floor. The pallet was broken down and one damaged bag was recovered and containerized. The released material was swept up and placed with the damaged freight into a 55 gallon poly drum. The pallet was then re-stacked and secured for shipment. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2022070684
item.description:
Report E-2022070684

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-08T21:10:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-07-11
  • City: SHREVEPORT
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: BAKER HUGHES OILFIELD OPERATIONS, INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On July 11, 2022, four (4) 125-gallon totes containing CRW9058A were damaged during a vehicular accident/rollover and released approximately two-hundred and seventy (270) gallons of product to the asphalt roadway and soil surface. Baker Hughes Oilfield Operations, Inc. (BH) retained Cura Emergency Services, LC (CES) to manage the remediation. CES dispatched a crew from Enhanced Environmental and Emergency (E3) to perform the necessary corrective action. E3 personnel transferred remaining product into two (2) 330-gallon totes, then deployed granular absorbents to the impacted asphalt roadway and worked them in with hand tools. Spent absorbents were collected and containerized into six (6) 55-gallon drums. The four (4) empty, damaged totes were deconstructed and containerized into one (1) roll-off box. On July 14, 2022, E3 personnel returned to the site and excavated the impacted soil area. Impacted soil was containerized into two (2) roll-off boxes for transport and disposal. Following approval of the corrective actions by Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality personnel, E3 demobilized noting no further actions required.

  • City: LAKE CHARLES

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Union Pacific Railroad
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The tank car was reported to be leaking by UPRR yard personnel. HMM Tom Robinson was called for a response. The tank car was leaking from both liquid valves and both vapor valves. The valves were all slightly opened, and three of the four plugs were less than tool tight. The residual chlorine was remediated, and the car was sealed and sent to destination.
